element_texts.text:
Dunbarton, May 29, 1856
Dearest Isaac,
If you come this week, you will not receive a letter if I write but something may detain you.  Yours came by Tuesday's mail.  I looked for is Saturday but not very confidently.  I am so glad Mayo does so well and does not trouble you very much - but how I want to see him.  Glad you had a pleasant journey, and found dear Lucy no worse.  Very glad the cape will be of use - I feared it would not answer for a city boy.  Hope you will get Lucy's garden in fine order and not be a very great while about it.  I am willing to spare you a little while but I do not love to think of your going West again.  A letter came from Mr Keyes Tuesday.  It is such woful chirography that I have no patience to decipher it all

There is considerable Du Quoin news in it. Mr. Wood is East assisting Miss Paine.  The babies have really had a hard time with Diarrhea - both of them, but both seem better now.  Willie has very perceptibly lost flesh - one night he did not really get to sleep till after two o'clock.  I would think he was asleep and just get nicely covered and disposed for a snooze myself when he would cry.  He cried about two hours very hard indeed.  I could do nothing to still him.  Wilder sleeps finely all the night.  I cannot leave him on the bed an instant, awake, without watching  - he creeps to the very Edge as Mayo used to and looks over without Mayo's carefulness.  I could put on short dresses now - we have enough ready to begin with, but this weather is too cold for the change. I keep thinking what a fine time you are all having together and am glad for you and it creeps into my mind now and then that I should have a nice time too if I

were there.  Cousin Samuel is here and does our running to Post Office, Store, &c.  A very quiet pleasant accommodating boy.  I've got a corraige for babies from Concord at $2,50 with permission to take it back when done using.  They enjoy it very much.  I can put both into it but is too heavy then for me to draw a great distance - so I take one when the other sleeps.  Everything is so beautiful here now, such a rich, bright, lively green, that I do wish Mother and Anna could see it.  We did not have one bright fine day while they were here.  Give great love to them and to all from me.  Thank Mother and Anna for the few lines from them, and tell Anna I shall be glad of the 'long letter' whenever she can write.  Mother is well as usual - sleeps better than before for a long time - thinks it must be because she gets the babies to sleep every day.  I shall hope the mail

of today will bring me another letter from you.
Lovingly, your own Nettie
Have had asparagus twice.  The Tomatoes seem no larger than when we set them out.  The cold weather delays them.  Corner of garden not planted yet.  We heard indirectly yesterday that Jenny was succeeding very well in her new employ.  You did not say a word about Percie.  I want to hear from him.
Antoinette Dunbarton
May 29 1856
Bangor

Dunbarton May 31, 1856
Dearest, - 
Yours of the 25th and 27th came by last mail and brought me great joy.  O how glad I was to hear so good news of Mayo.  If he only continues to be good, it will be better yet.  Hope dear Lucy has recovered from the effect of the cold and has not taken any more.  I should like to see you gardening with the help of the two little boys.  O how cold it is!  The air seems to come from snow banks.  We have had two or three very warm days, but all the rest have been very unusually cold for the season.  The tomatoes seem to be growing back into the ground, leaves pinched & purple & shrivelled. The peas look best of anything in our garden.  Grass looks finely everywhere.

the dear babies are better one day and worse the next.  Wilder as well as Willie. I have given them a little spice tea containing all spice.  It seems to check the diarrhea somewhat.  I don't know but charcoal would be preferable.  They want to held most of the time.  I do love to comfort the little troubled creatures.  They both creep when they feel pretty well.  Willie goes backward and gets over the ground (or floor, faster than Wilder.  How kind Lucy is to think of sending one the sack and bonnet.  It will certainly save me a good many stitches, but I feel as if she ought not to send them.  Haven't put the short-dresses on yet, it is so cold.  I hope you will go to Milo & Brownville with Anna.
We succeed very well with the babies and all.  Asenath will go nex week I suppose and Mary Stinson come.  She had had three applications from Concord, & one from Goffstown.

but comes here for the sake of being nearer to home.  One seemed pleased with the idea of coming.  I expect she is a greater worker than Asenath, much more rapid, but may not be quite so good natured.
Jenny is at home to day.  Seems quite satisfied with her week's work and Mr. Percy told father he thought they should have a good school.  Father was in school about an hour last night - reported favorably.   The Committee visited her last Wednesday.  
You cannot imagine how nicely the little ones slept last night. Even till morning light appeared.
I do rejoice that Mary and Percie enjoy themselves together and get along so comfortably.  It would be hard for Lucy to look on if they did not, as well as trouble all of you.
Mr. Charles Marshall arrived on Tuesday.

and preaches for father next Sabbath.
Tomorrow is June 1.  Mayo's birth day.  "Mover" longs to see him and 'drand pa' and 'drand ma' talk of him often & miss him greatly, & seem to want him back almost as much as his mother does. I did not know but they would be glad & relieved to miss his noise for a time, but they never speak of that.  I must stop or the rest will be wearied with the babies.  I shall hardly need to write again shall I? Unless I have something new from you.
Love very much from 
Nettie.
All the rest send love.  Asenath wishes you would return before she leaves.
Antoinette  Dunbarton
May 31 1856
Bangor

21 Jan 1857
Elyria, Ohio-
Wednesday Jan 21
My dearest,-
I believe I have not written to you since Saturday - A letter came Saturday night from you having been a week on the way came round by Cleveland, - and this morning the Dr. to my great joy came in with two letters from you and one from George. All good news. O how good it is to have absent friends well - it compensates, in part, for the pain of separation to hear that you are well - If we only all keep so while you are away, I shall feel it matter for very great rejoicing. What will you think when I tell you that Anne has

not come yet, and that ever since a week ago last Monday I have put all the wood in the furnace and brought all the wood for the kitchen, except once, - filling the box - and been up before seven and build the kitchen fire &c. - The fire in the furnace has not gone out since she went away - then we had the ironing of last week to do and baking this week and all sorts of things - and O how cold it has been constantly - Dr said at eight oclock in Eve - one night it was 10 degrees below zero and at two oclock in the day time it was either two or four degrees below. There is a good deal of snow too and very good sleighing - It was warmer yes

terday - snowed about all day Anna was over here an hour, with stockings on over shoes.
I bought print for a dress last monday and carried it to the dress maker to make concluding I could save enough to pay for it doing without a girl a week or so!
Sabbath day Jennie went to meeting in the A.M. and I in the Eve. I heard Mr. Havel of the Methodist chh., and had a hard time, unless I judged hardly. It was most tediously long and dull and hard and loud. and all seemed weary. How good you were to write me so much news about Du Quoin people - I am glad to hear about them - I should like to have Mr & Mrs Keys come

here, but should want you at home of course, and you will be I reckon. George is well and evidently enjoying the winter finely.
Little Wilder is fast asleep on the bed - dear good little boy he is. It is so much pleasanter today that I shall take him over to see Anna when he wakes, I think He seems quite well - Jennie I think is decidedly better than when you left. She asks almost every day if she shall not stay at home to help me, but I do not love to have her. She helps all she can out of school. You speak of sending a foolscap sheet to me on the 15th that has not come yet. Anna had a letter last night from you. No news from Bangor since you left - O how I think of you, & long for you. Lovingly Nettie
Written upside down on the top:
Shall hope I hear, from the result of your trip to Springfield. It takes all the letters a week to come - nearly

Elyria, Saturday Eve, 24 Jan. 57
My own dearest,-
I wrote to you yesterday and I feel just like beginning again tonight - Another letter came to day mailed at Springfield last Wednesday - came quick, did it not? Perhaps you are at DuQuoin to night - If you left Springfield Wednesday night you are, - and I hope have heard from us again - The new girl does finely - takes nice care of the furnace, and keeps all neat & clean. We eat most of the time now in the kitchen - It is altogether too cold for the dining room - Anna tries to persuade me to have the stove moved into the dining room - I have not decided to do it yet - I hope it will not be so cold a long time. I had a letter from your

mother to night - She had heard from you & had mailed a letter to you at Du Quoin - Poor Rev. Rider, she says suffers dreadfully now. Says he never would try to swallow again if it were not duty. O how mother misses dear Lucy - her every letter shows it in some way - Baby fast asleep on the bed - Jennie looking over her French lesson at the stand. Elisabeth just gone down to the furnace - (clock striking nine) - she will lift a stick I could not move & put it into the furnace xxx I just been down cellar - always get down at night - to see that all is right about the fire - other than this have not taken a bit of care of the furnace since the girl came. She seems careful. I was a little afraid of the shine of her eyes, at first, but I guess she will do well. good night my dearest - "I miss

thee at the dawning gray - But most beneath the lamp's pale beam - I miss thee from my side." I dreamed one night that you came home - It was a glad surprise - But it was rather rainy awakening to the reality.
Sabbath Eve. A most delightful day and evening - I went to meeting in the P.M. and we both went this evening leaving the sleeping baby under Elisabeth's care. He did not wake while we were away, O I do so long for little Mayo sometimes and the tears come all at once, now and then when I look at Wilder, alone.  Whose fate is most to be envied? Those who have done with life and are safe in Heaven, or his who lives, take life's pleasures & its sorrows & battle with its storms, its temptations

and its sins?

Little Wilder says "papa" very sweetly - always points to the door if we ask him where his father is. It is strange how he clings to me since you went away - perhaps not strange either.
Jennie has seemed pretty well since the first week she began to take her pills. She has an excellent appetite - has some idea of sending to you a list of articles devoured at one meal I believe! Really we have not starved at all since you left us - It seems to me we dispose of about as much as when you were here to help. I don't know but you ought to appoint a guardian over us, in your absence, lest you find yourself seriously impoverished, when you come to examine our bill of provisions We have just got some excellent new potatoes at Starr

5) Last Friday & got cloth and lining for a basque and to day     Miss Crow has been here and fitted it and also fitted the calico you got.  The latter will make a very pretty dress indeed.  I like it very much.  We got the new coal oil Friday too, darker in color than our last but good they call it.  And I think it is. 
It has been a beautiful day to day.  Thermometer stood at zero at seven this morning, but it has moderated fast.
Tomorrow is the funeral at one o'clock P.M. Mr & Mrs. Weeks came to night.  Anna wants me to go down there early in the morning, and I

shall do so.  Probably be there about all day.  If I can be of any use.
Wilder says papa is gone to Ilis. in Springfield.  We get along nicely with the Children at night.
Your loving Nettie
I must just tell you it is very evident that Charlie has not forgotten his father yet.  He says papa very prettily when we talk about you.  You would be pleased to see the face change from the troubled, anxious look when I say "dear papa gone" to a merry laugh when I say "papa come home see Charley".  He won't have any thing to do with Zillah when she awakes in the night without crying about it.

6 Feb. 57 [?]
Elyria, Friday, 6th Feb., /57
My dearest, -
I have just scribbled a letter to your mother with nothing in it, and now sit down to write you one of the same sort.  Yours of the 26 came Thursday - I am so glad you are so well.  Unfortunately, the weather is warmer & you will stay to stake out town lots I suppose!  I know you will come as soon as it is best, and we are really very comfortable, too bad that you had got no letters telling you so.  But you must have got more before this.  We have had a great rain and the snow is almost entirely gone, and it is so warm it seems as if Spring were at hand.  Wilder

improves rapidly in walking, though not talking. He has been full of pranks all morning.  He helped me make the bed, ie, he pulled off the clothes as fast as I got them on and he has since been most vigorously brushing the carpet with broom corn brush.  Then discovering my writing he came in haste to pull my paper and nudge my elbow laughing all while so roguishly.
A letter came from Mrs. Rider Wednesday.  Poor suffering man.  Two or three days he suffered very much from hunger, being able to take only water, but swallows easier now  takes broma.   Quite a hole in his mouth.  The hole extends almost from ear to ear and is three inches wide, I think, in the widest place.  Anna thought I had better

not read about it.  Hattie had told me some of it.  There is a revival in Brownville, a steady, silent worker Lirrin Searles indulges a trembling hope Almeda has some joy in the midst of sorrow and care.
I went over to Anna's after school yesterday to go to the sewing circle, but we concluded not to go and she came home with me and we both called on Miss Woodbury, who is out of school with bronchitis, not able to speak loud.  Mr. Wilbur called in my absence, much to my regret, but Jenny was here.  Hattie was here to dinner yesterday.  We had mutton steak. I paid my milkman $2.32 for the months milk.  Have between three & four dollars now.  Shall

need more money if you are gone a great while longer.  Some thing takes it away pretty fast.  Yesterday, Elisabeth put that cord and a half of wood that was here before you went, into the cellar and piled it up quite nicely.  I did not ask her to do it.  I said one day that it must be done, and she seemed to take it for granted she was to do it.  Kept asking every day, "Shall I put the wood in the cellar to day"?   I told her to wait for better weather it was so wet yesterday in the bright sunshine, she did it. You know Ann sent for you to put dozen sticks out of her way.  The stove wood not gone yet, but I must find someone to saw some before long.  Jennie sends love.
All good be with you,
Lovingly Nettie
Anna says she shall write to mother that we shall probably be here all summer.  She is very anxious mother sh'd come.  If we are here, I should be sorry not to have her come.

Feb 20, 1857
Elyria, Ohio -
Friday 20th Feb, 1857
My dearest - 
Last night came three good letters from yourself of the 9th, 10th and 11th, and one good long one from Albina. The first that has come from Milo since we came here I think.  Was I not a happy child!  I reckon!  And it is so good to hear that you are so well.  Truly we should be grateful.  And your letters this time make me unusually happy for I think you must be coming home before a very great while.  You say one more day work at laying out lots and then the a R. R. Location, and I expected the

next sentence was - "then I am ready to go home" and my mouth began to stretch in anticipation and you did not say it, as it happened but I took it for granted you meant it, and allowed myself to be glad over it.  Anna was here when Jennie came from the office, so she was just in season for the letters.  They are all well at Milo.  Albina thinks she never enjoyed a winter more.  Mother had written to them for advice about coming to Ohio in the Spring, so I guess she thinks of coming.  Wednesday I had a letter again from little Eliza Paddock, of Homer, Ill. where I used to teach.  I wish you could go there & I too.
This has been a rainy week.  Every

day except Tuesday, and every night, I think.  It rains very steadily to day, freezing as it falls making it awfully slippery.  Do not expose yourself too much in the winter wind or carry that heavy instrument too much.  I want to see your weather-beaten face. I shall begin to be jealous of the Prairie Winds! Don't like the idea of their being too familiar with a face that belongs to me!  No news from the cosmopolitan yet.  I should think it was time.  I am glad the church building advances or is likely to do so.  What can the matter be with Dear Sprague?  He ought to be the foremost in the matter. Hasn't he a good wife, or has an irresistible desire to

hoard come over him?  Baby hits me now and then and I do not write pretty at all.  He does not make much progress in getting acquainted with the girl.  He is a constant appendage to my skirts whenever I go out of the room.  He does not like to have me out of his sight a moment.  I long to know what he will do when he sees you.  Yes, twenty thousand is quite an Estate truly.  I hope we shall do our duty with it and be thankful for it.  May we be rich in Heavenly treasure.
Then you have some land north of Du Quoin yet unsold, do you not?
All well as usual at the Dr's.
You own loving
Nettie
Jennie sends love to you.

Brother John lost a sweet little girl this fall, she was just six weeks older than Olie.  They were always very much attached to each other.  When Olie was sick, as long as she took any interest in anything, she would ask to go and see Hittie.  After she died Hittie used to say to her mother she

wanted to go to heaven and be with little Olie".  Dear little one, we little that her wish was so soon to be realised.  
Her mother took her and went to visit a sister living at St Cloud.  The day that John expected her home, he got a letter saying that Hittie was very sick and in about two hours afterwards she got home with her body.  Her spirit had gone where no stain of earth shall ever soil it.  It was a great affliction, but it is pleasant to think they are together.

Nettie, Elyria, Sept. 22,'58
Elyria, Ohio 
Wednesday morning, Sept. 22
My dearest Isaac - 
I do not know as a letter will reach you, but will just write enough to let you know that we are doing very well, as well as we can without you.  The first night after you left the children were rather restless and we did not rest very well any of us; but last night Wilder hardly stirred at all, and baby only two or three times.  Wilder had a good deal of diarrhea yesterday, but feeding on rice will set him right I think.  Dr & Anna & baby & I rode out to Mr. Halls, after they returned from the Depot Monday.  Had a fine ride. I did not get out, but sat in the carraige with sleeping Charley while they were in.  Yesterday Dr. brought up some tomatoes for me, and Anna was here a while & Sophia Karr also.  No letters since you left.  I do want to know how you are prospering.  Kate & Rollin do very well.  Rollin is gone now to Mr. Potter's to see if the meal or bran is come.  & Wilder

with him in his little carraige.  Anna & I think some of riding down to call on Mrs. Ely's mother, who is home, this P.M.
May all good be with you in all your  way.  I shall look for a letter Saturday, shall I, or will you have no opportunity to write?
Baby clings to me - so do excuse such letters.  Wilder asks for your plate every meal time & sets up a chair in your place.
Loving, Nettie

Nettie      Elyria
Aug 16 1859
Elyria, Aug. 16, 1859
Dearest,
'The day is done', and in spite of my poor eyes I must sit down and pen a record for you.  Clara has just come up to tell me Wilder was a good boy to day, & I felt so glad I could not wait till morning to tell you of it.  I have really felt troubled all day with the fear that you might regret taking him.  He is so different from little Mayo that I think he may not be as pleasant a traveling companion.  But your favorite maxim comes to my relief - "The trouble" &c.
I remained at Dr's half an hour more after you left, and picked up and shut up, in the

front part of the house, and then walked very snail-paced home to a little forsaken, disconsolate Charlie and a little smiling, quiet baby.  
As for Charlie, he did be comforted till after dinner, when he went to sleep and waked up feeling better.  We ate a lonesome dinner, Charlie pointing every few minutes to the vacant places, and saying "Papa"  "Wilder".  Then we both lay down on the lounge together & went to sleep.  Then after, I rummaged and regulated some drawers, and wrote a letter to Dunbarton.  
The thermometer stood for several hours at 86 degrees between four & five, Zillah took Charlie & went down for the butter and mailed the letter, and called for the tin at Northrups, but he was very sorry to say it was not made, and would surely

have it done by tomorrow night.  She also called to see Clara and brought home some nice meat and tarts, that she said Anna left for us.  I was so full of my own reflections at Anna's before you started, that I am afraid I did not do anything properly that I tried to do.  I don't believe they found sugar enough in their tea at any rate!  I began to hem Wilder's bib.  Did you take it?  I found a few ears of sweet corn, and had some beets with it, for dinner & the potatoes left of yesterday.  Charley & I went to the garden together. He has kept very close to mama today.  Good night.
I wrote to Eliza Paddock also this P.M. while Zillah was gone.
17 - Good morning!  It is delightful.  The children did well through the night.  Baby perhaps did not sleep quite as well as usual, Charlie better.  This morning

Charlie and I went over to the Waldo's a few moments, for the walk, and to find out how Mrs. Biggs did.  She has a nice English nurse.  It was Anna Biggs that you saw asleep at the Waldo's.  We came home and went out to the garden, and gathered squashes and cucumbers , and lima beans and I have washed the cucumbers  and put them with the others.  The tomatoes grew ever so much yesterday. Charlie is sitting on the floor amusing himself and myself by drawing onto his little feet a pair of my big stocking that happened to be in my basket.
Mrs. Waldo said Mr Nesbitt hardly wanted anybody but Mr. Waldo about him.  He is so weak that he fainted in being moved from one bed to another.
6 o'clock P.M.  I'll finish writing so that Zillah may take this to the office to night.  After dinner I mended a little and Charlie and I

took a short nap.  Then I took baby awhile and administered to her comfort, and then about 4 o'clock I went and called on Mrs. Snow and daughters, on Miss Simons and Mrs. Toplift. Found Libbie here when I got back with a letter from Milo from mother. Part for you and part for Anna.  I sent her part back with Dr. by Libbie.  Libbie looked pale and sick.  I guess it was too much for her to go to Cleveland, or she ate something that hurts her perhaps.  I felt sorry for her.  She said she had been taking medicine. Said her father was coming up here to night.
I am impatient to hear from you to know whether all is well with you.  Whether Wilder troubles either of you.  Tell him mama made the basket

out of the piece of his hat last night, and it is all ready for him when he comes home.  Mama thinks about him almost all the time and wants him so very much to be a good boy and mind papa and aunty, and say yes ma'am and yes sir and not step on ladies dresses or go before them.
Please pay a little attention to Wilder's fingernails as often as your own.  Now, laugh at me.  Love to Anna and all.
Your own
Nettie.

Nettie     Elyria
August 22 1859
Elyria
Monday, August 22, 1859
Dearest,
I mailed a letter to you Thursday morning after you left and Saturday morning also.  Saturday night came a letter and deed from Mr. Keyes.  Your letter mailed at Lewiston came Friday night. I was so glad to hear from you.  We take it for granted you reached Bangor at least Saturday.  Herbert was up here Friday evening.  Brought me some plums. I suppose he started this morning for the East.  Expecting to be in Dunbarton next Friday night.  I hope you may be there next Sabbath. 
Saturday I gathered cucumbers

squashes, beans, beets & corn for selves and the cow & pigs.  Zillah and I went out and cut the sage.  I heard Libbie parse, and had some calls in the P.M.  Libbie does not feel well, but I guess she will be better in few days.  Her tongue looks bad and she seems to have no appetite.  The Dr. too feels badly, could not go to meeting Sabbath day.  Rev. Jenkins read a sermon in the morning & Mr. Goodspeed told the Dr. he did not hear one word of it.  It was unfortunate.  The Methodist minister preached in the P.M.  The Dr. could have done far better, though all he said was very good, but my head ached with the noise he made saying it.  Dr. and Libbie both seem to feel some better to day.  I have been out for cucumbers & squashes

Got 56 cucumbers all but ten of them put into the pickle.  I do not know what will become of all our garden sauce.  I do not feel much like eating myself & Dr. & Libbie eat almost nothing.  The girls get rid of considerable however.
It is so good to hear that Wilder does not trouble you.  I do hope he will continue in well doing.  Charlie is a very good boy - is learning to dress himself alone.  It has taken one of us about all the time to play with him.  He seems quite inclined to make a 'papa' of the Dr.  Even sits in his lap, takes fruit from him, runs to meet him, and says by by when he goes.
Mrs. Wilbur came up Saturday to see me.  I hardly know

where to direct this letter - thinking you may go this week to Milo or to Dunbarton.  I'll write to George, so that if you go there, you will hear from us and send this to Bangor I think.
Evening - I walked down and called on Mrs. Brooks &  Mr. Hunt this P.M. and went to Cogwell's to see if he would mend my shoe.  I got a pair of thick walking shoes & a pair of thin slippers for myself.
Dr. has just been up to supper - does not feel very well.  Said supper improved him however.
In haste
Your Nettie

Nettie    Elyria
Aug 27, 1859
Elyria, Ohio -
Saturday, Aug 27, 1859
My dearest,
Dr. & I both hoped for letters last night, but neither of us received any.  Anna's, written at Montreal, came Thursday night.  Libbie was greatly pleased that there was a page for her especially.
This is a June morning.  Yesterday the Gov. Chase was here, and a crowd of people - so I hear by way of the Dr.  More than half were ladies.  Clara came at the time.  Libbie took her clothes home this morning, thought she should be up this P.M.  It is ridiculous that Anna is away, as well as yourself, in time of Bartlett pears for never it seems to me, was anything more delicious. Charlie would not have
...tomorrow.  Much love to Anna.  Whatever shall I do without her here 
Lovingly, Nettie
Perhaps you are at Milo now.  Mother & Charlie are about getting ready to start.  I do hope Mother is well and all of you.
Love to all.

anything to do with them at first but he has overcome his prejudices entirely.  We shall probably do the canning next week.  I found a dozen ripe tomatoes to day - the third time I have picked these.  Charlie and I have fine times gardening.  He always takes his little pail and follows me.  He is perfectly good about touching things himself.  It affects my back some.  Guess I shall take one of the girls with me hereafter to do the stooping chiefly.  
I think there were fifteen water melons in the garden.  We took one off yesterday.  It was very fine.  Two more are plenty ripe.  I will give one to Betty, I guess.  All Mr. Mussey's were stolen last Sabbath.  Nobody touches ours.  I reckon they are afraid of me.  The rabbits have been in the garden once or twice.  I found some cabbages badly marked.
Libbie is reading Robinson Crusoe

and is quite interested therein. 
Does Wilder think as much of his thumb as ever?  Baby begins to use hers in the same way.  Shall we let her?
Eve.  Again 'the day is done' and the week also.  I do so miss you in the evenings.  Here all alone I sit by the little table, knitting, knitting, thinking, thinking, listening sometimes to the breathing, soft & low, of the wee ones sleeping near.   Baby is as good as ever.  Charlie good too.  Clara has been up to night & brought me some nice pears "to last me over the Sabbath" she said.  I do wish you and Anna had some of them.  Libbie came up this P.M.  She takes a great fancy to baby and baby seems to like her as well.
Monday 29 - I went to meeting yesterday P.M.  We had good preaching.  Rev Mr. Dana of Oberlin.  Dr. said the A.M. discourse was on Divine Sovereignty.

treated quite in the old way and exceedingly pleasing Mr. Perry and Mr. Potter, &c.  The text in the afternoon was "Ye are the light of the world".  The Dr. was up this morning and brought some more pears.  We shall can some tomorrow.  Libbie has been up also, but went back to eat dinner with her father.  I sent seventy cucumbers down to Clara for pickles to day - just the right size.
Please do not forget to find the little book "Wee Wee Songs".  The title of a book advertised in the Independent attracted me "Here and Beyond, or the New Man the True Man" by Rev Hugh Smith Carpenter.  I do not know as you an spend money for books though just now - I am going down to the Dr's to night to look over the pears and make arrangements for

Nettie   Elyria
Sept 1, 1859
Elyria, Thursday, Sept 1, 1859
My own dearest, -
I rose this morning thinking I would sit me down at once and write to you, but the children and there after breakfast, some pears to look after, pickles &c, and the garden, little jobs of mending & various interruptions delayed me, and now it is two oclock P.M.  Last evening about half past Eight the Dr. came up, so kindly, and brought me a letter from you mailed the 24th, and one from Dunbarton mailed the 29th at Concord, whither George, Jenny and Herbert had gone for pleasure, I suppose; may be shopping.
The Dr. had no letter and has had none, except the one written from Montreal.  I do not think either
...hemorrhage of the lungs while she was gone.  Looks pale & thin now - has slight cough.
Your Nettie

of you have done as well as usual about writing, have you?  Too much else to think of perhaps.  The Dr. was rather disappointed last night.  O how good it will be to have you get home again, I should think. Clara did well.  I was down there most of the day Tuesday.  The canning is done, if it only stays done, and we have pickled some pears also, both Clara & I.  The Dr got Mr. Austin to send up a half bushel of peaches to me.  I told him only half a bushel for they are $2.00 per bush.; but then seem not to be many, so I secured a few more.  I hall have to send for Mr. Hurman, I suppose.  These are very nice ones indeed.
Mrs. Wilber & the little boys came up yesterday and spent the afternoon.  Libby was here too. Quite an assistance in amusing the little

people. Charley enjoyed himself with them very much.  They seemed to agree perfectly.
Mr. Wilbur, by last tidings, was up at Margrethe.  Not expected home till next week.  I want to see Wilder - some.  And how I should love to see the little ones you are seeing at Milo & Bangor, as well as dear Almeda and hers.  I am very glad you wrote to Dunbarton.  Mother wrote that they expected the marriage to take place on Tuesday of this week, I suppose.  If so, they are married, and what next they wrote not.  Miss Newcomb was to remain till after the wedding.  I am obliged to be very careful of my eyes, and it is quite a trial, now you are away, not to read as much as I like, & then I want to sew too.

I think our tomatoes need trimming.  They ripen very slowly indeed.  Charley is a very good boy indeed.  He calls Wilder & papa regularly every morning and when we have cake at night wants one put on the shelf for Wilder. 
Mrs. Mussey has sent for met to go and make a call with her.  Now I must go away & get ready.
Eve.  Well I really did do quite and afternoon work after half past four.  I hesitated about going, I felt so tired when Mrs. Mussey sent over, but I laid down & went to sleep and awakened and dressed and started.  We called on Mr. & Mrs. Catlin and had a very pleasant call.  Then on Mrs. Washburn & Mrs. Vincent.  Then I went into the Tin Shop to ask one of them to come to sodder the cans for peaches & on the way home we called on Mrs. Richards, the sister of Mrs. Simons.  Mrs. Vincent had

Nettie    Dunbarton
July 21, 1860
Dunbarton, July 21, 1860
My very dear Isaac, 
Here I am safely arrived at the dear old homestead.  I reached here just at tea time last night.  Find mother very feeble and father ditto just now.  He was not able to preach last Sabbath and will not be able tomorrow.  He seems to feel quite discouraged.  Almost every other day he has severe blind headache, so that he cannot read or study or write a sermon. He could not read it or read the hymns to accompany.  Last Sabbath a sermon was read in the A.M. and the people went to Baptist chh in the P.M.  Will do so tomorrow also.  I found that Miss Colby

from Bow here helping Mother.  They call her girls good help, and very pleasant,  Give her $1,00 per week.  She is fifty years old. I must tell you a little about my journey.  O you can hardly imagine how dusty it was from Cleveland to Erie.  We could have no window up and it was so close that it made me sick (sick headache).  But from Erie to Buffalo it rained finally, and I felt better at once.  We left Buffalo about six oclock.  Got into Albany about five.  Had rain about all night.  Slept some.  Left Albany 5.30, reached Springfield, 10.15 Thursday A.M.  Had just time to get a cup of coffee, and crackers, say good by to my company and get my seat in cars for Worcester.
Mrs. Nelson's brother met her at the depot, and Mrs. Doolittle and Rev E. went by carraige to Suffield Coun.

I got to Worcester at one o'clock - just dinner time precisely, but I was so tired that I declined dinner and lay down on the bed in my room at the Bay State, and went to sleep.  Had a good nap.  Then & and sat in the parlor a while and looked about.  I found I would be just as soon home to wait in Worcester till 11,15 Friday A.M. as to divide my waiting between Worcester and Manchester.  So I thought I would be contented where I was.  I did not know where to find my cousins.  About four I started out to walk and went into three or four stores and then walked on simply to while away the time.  Happening to turn my eye, I saw S. A. Porter on a door plate right on Main street.  I knew it was the name of the Uncle of cousin Carrie & Frances

Putnam.  So I ventured to ring the bell and ask for them and so doing learned that Carrie would be home from her teaching in half an hour.  So I sat down and waited with her aunt, a very cordial, pleasant fine appearing lady, perhaps forty five years old.  Carrie wad delighted to see me and said Frances was to close her school that night (as she also did) and was going to her home in Pembroke Friday, so we should be together as far as Manchester.  They urged me so much to stay there over night that Carrie & I went over to the Hotel and got my night clothes and went to the office and told them I would take the key to my room and be back to go down with my trunk to the Depot at Eleven the next day.  This was pleasanter than sleeping at Hotel alone.  I had a fine time with cousins & with Mr. & Mrs. Porter & had company to Manchester.  Got to Parker's at

three oclock or a little past.  They were very busy haying, but spared a horse and the young man from the store to come with me.
Do tell me everything very soon.  How is dear baby and how is your cough.  I do so want the children.  I have wished Charlie was with me many times.  Tell mother I wish I could send her some blueberries.  The are so nice.  Love to all - a little girl waits for the letter.
Good by - Tell mother to kiss you for me & you may kiss her on both cheeks.  
Lovingly Nettie

Nettie    Dunbarton
July 21, 1860
Saturday Evening 7o'c July 21, 1860
My own dear Isaac -
I wrote a very hurried letter to you this morning, partly while a little girl was waiting to take it to the office as father is unable to go anywhere to read or write or exert himself in any way, though he does feel better to day than yesterday.
This PM the same little girl brought me a nice letter from you and one from George to Father.  O how glad was I to hear so soon from you all.  I can never thank you enough for being to good to write.  I dreamed last night that baby May was sick and I felt troubled and anxious.  Am glad the girls seem inclined to do well.  I felt sure they would try.  Tell Wilder the rain did not wet mama, but it did her much good.  It kept the dust away

which poured in in such quantities before that mama could not have the window up and that made it too close and warm to breathe comfortably.  The weather has been very warm, until to day it has rained all day.  This evening it is bright and a beautiful new moon appears just over the church.  I hope the girl won't forget to water the plants in the pots now and then, or that there is a piece of cheese down cellar!  If we have such warm weather as most since I left home I shall wish I had the thin dress I left.  Father had some grass cut yesterday and to day it is nicely soaked; and Mr. Colby did not even come as he might this morning and cock it up.  It is all flat and cannot now be touched till Monday.  
George, by father's advice, has sent a negative to the Hophunter people.  He does not know what to do yet.  Will be home next week Friday if nothing happens.  A committee at Portsmouth

N. H. but sent to him by Edward Ryder to come and supply them.  Somebody from Portsmouth heard him preach at Concord.  He could not go at that time, but they still expect him to come.  Don't know whether he will or not.  The people of Yarmouth are very Earnest and Enthusiastic about his going there.  The people of Brewer & of Orland wanted him, but he told them it was useless to call him. Said no at once.  George thinks after he comes home and sees father he can decide on something and then be ready to go to Ohio.  He is hardly inclined to go to Portsmouth at all, even to preach a Sabbath or two.  I have been reading some to father to day.  It is quite hard for him not to be able to read.
Some blueberries were sent last night from Mr. Marshalls.  They are very nice & Mrs. Abbott sent a pail of cherries.  Sour of course but very good cooked.  Harris Ryder is sick and had a sort of shock of numb palsy.  It is feared he may never be well.  Both the older brothers are to be here soon.

Fanny Parker (Mrs. Dr. Carr) is very unwell, and people think will not live long.  That match was of her mother's making.  Mr. Ray still preaches at Goffstown.
Monday night.  So may people are calling that I fear my letter will not be ready for tomorrows mail.  I run away now from company.  It rained all this A. M. but cleared away at noon.  People were quite surprised to see me but all seem very glad.  Father laughs about your addressing George as Rev.  Says no minister is Entitled to it before ordination.  Says G, thought you did it for a joke.  Two of my cans of fruit knocked each other and there was a considerable dent in one, through which the strawberry leaked out and soaked the wrapping paper and made a slight spot on my ladies cloth cape, which however was easily remedied.  This was all the harm.  Father went to the church yesterday P.M. and read scripture and commented thereon getting through finely, but had been not more than five minutes home before blindness and headache descended. But he seems to feel pretty

Will you forget to gather Whitlavia seeds?  I am enjoying myself just as much as I could without my Isaac and wee little ones.

Nettie   Dunbarton
July 28, 1860
Dunbarton New Hampshire
Saturday, July 28, 1860
My very dear Isaac -
I have written two letters to you, and received from you the same number.  And I believe I cannot let this mail go today without writing again.  O I cannot tell how very strange is seems to be away from you and our little ones.  My plan has been to stay here two weeks after George came.  That would be just two weeks more - as George came last night, and then spend a week or ten days among the Westboro friends and then home as fast as possible.  They try to persuade me to remain another week here but I do not really think I shall, hardly see how I can possibly unless it be to accommodate George, and I hardly think it will be needful on that account.  I went down to Goffstown to meet George yesterday

as father was not able.  He had another turn of blindness and headache yesterday A.M.  Not so severe as sometimes, and he feels quite comfortable to day.  I called at Esq. Steeles while waiting for the cars.  She seemed delighted to see me, knew me at once and urged me to visit them.  I saw some of my old scholars too.  I fastened the horse by the trees south of the church, because the horse is a little afraid of cars, and walked to Esq Steele and the Depot.  George said knew me as soon as he saw me coming though he did not know who was with me.  It was John Steele.  We had a nice ride home, it being a delightful day.  We expect some of the Yarmouth people here to see father the coming week.  The church has voted to give George a call last week and the Society were to act as soon as possible, so that the legal document has probably reached Bangor before now.  George had decided to stay another week till a letter reached him Tuesday night that was mailed at

Manchester Monday morning telling of fathers continued ill health and requesting him to come this week if possible. So he is here but has agreed on an Exchange with Mr. Ray of  Goffstown for tomorrow.
He rather likes the idea of going to Yarmouth. I imagine, though he thinks it may be rather a difficult place.  Mr. N. Parker of Belfast and Mr. Thurston of Searsport came with him, in the boat, to Boston, and introduced themselves and had a good deal of talk about the place and people.  The church has just divided on some question of politics.
The democratic portion, including the chief wealth have seceded, and they too are wanting a minister at once.  The original church wants to keep the young people and the new one to draw them away; so there will be this strife among them.  Any minister who goes there will need Grace to help.
Last Tuesday A.M., I drove for father & mother over to Mr. Rays, and then mother & I went up to the P.O in the afternoon.  When father

came to unharness the horse he found a loose shoe and it troubled him at once.  You may recollect that he likes to do things now.  So I told him I thought I could go after tea and get the two hind shoes set as he wanted.  He harassed Charley for me and I went to the blacksmiths to get the work done. Wednesday I did not feel very well.  I dreamed about baby during the night.  Thought you and I were journeying with her; and by some means found me all alone - had lost you and her both - waked up in great agitation and could not asleep again for some time!
Mrs Safford came over and stayed some time.  Mrs Brown came and fitted a pretty print that I got for mother at Worcester.  I wanted it fitted so I could make it right up for her.  So Mrs Brown helped us an hour or so. Mother has not been as well the last three days, but I think feels more comfortable this morning.  It seems sad to me to think of my parents.  This Miss Colby who helps them is very good if she would remain, but she has engaged to pick hops by Sept 1 and then she want to visit six or eight

weeks among brothers & sisters, and then will not promise to return.  She has a good home & money enough and is not obliged to work, and of [unclear] does not want to do so.  And then she is away from acquaintances, and sees little company of her sort, and doubtless feels lonesome, accustomed to be in her brothers family with his children.  Since I came home, I have written for the parents, to Westboro, according to father's dictation, to ascertain whether a Miss Burgess, aged 24 could be obtained by Sept 1.  The friends then spoke of her to father another as a very suitable person for them and one needing a home.  I made the case as discouraging as I could so that if she comes, she need not be discontented and go back.  But it is hard to get help.  A young girl cannot be contented.  A family in the house to board there, would be just the thing but where can such be found?  If the Miss Burgess says nay then I do not know what next.  I sometimes think

father will not be able to preach much longer.  But he may get better.  Mother thought when he was first taken he would not get well.  T'was a sort of cholera morbus the first week.  
Had I better get shoes and boots for myself while here?  I do not really need any just now, but they are cheaper here.  Can't I get that sail cloth for pants for you from Boston while I am at Westboro?  If I do not go to Boston myself, I have cousins who go very often.  I think I will try - I do hope mother will not suffer any working or overdoing to weary her while I am away. You will take good care of her I know.  Is not it strange that your cough hold on so.  I do want to hear that it is passing away.  It does me good to hear such news from the children.  Tell the girls, if it is best, that I expect they are doing finely and take nice care of everything especially of the baby.  Will the little creature forget her mother?

I hope Anna will be up often.  Love to her and to you all.  Especially a great deal to yourself.
From your own Nettie
They want George to supply a Sabbath or two at Franklin St. Chh Manchester.  While he is at home, during the minister's vacation.

yesterday morning, and took with him George's affirmative answer to the Call  He is to go there in Oct. and supply two Sabbaths, and then arrange with them for Ordination the first of Nov.  George says he does not feel nearly as happy as he has done, just now.  He feels as if he had just shouldered all the realities and labors and trials of life.  Was about to enter an untried and mysterious pathway.  I can sympathise with these feelings a little at any rate.  They are a kin to what some young women feel after promising to be married.  They are feelings hardly to be explained, only to be felt, deep down in the heart.  Trust, blessed trust in our overruling, and all sustaining Providence is the only antidote.  A young man like George needs a constant spirit of prayer for himself, and Christian friends to hold him up by their prayers and counsels.  May he have these and is safe.  
Yesterday P.M. just giving Dr B. time to get

Nettie    Dunbarton
Aug, 1860

his answer and be gone, two men from Hopkinton were over here (not knowing that George would be at home till Aug. 1 as he wrote them), clothed with authority to put the salary at $750.00 and remove all objections, and  secure his services there.  If they had come over Monday they probably would have been successful as G. then had no other call and was under no obligations to Yarmouth.  But as it happened they were not quite one day too late.  They seemed greatly disappointed, but could not blame anyone but themselves.  George and I were away when they came.  Rev John Kimball sent for us to visit there and we had gone.  Called at LeRoy Mill's on the way home.  This P.M. we are invited to Mr. Brighams.  I still think I shall leave here either the last of next week or more like the first of the week after so as to have one more Sabbath for George to preach.  Whether father will then be able to preach cannot be known.  He feels some better, more cheerful and has a better appetite.  Dr. Burbank told him he thought the trouble was indigestion.  He as complained of nausea all the while.  Mrs. Brown has just been in - wants us all to go over there this week some time to visit.  Father & mother send much love.  Do you hear anything of Jenny?  How is she these days?  Give love to her.  I would write again to her, but it does seem as if the time all ran away furiously.
You own Nettie

Nettie    Dunbarton
Aug 1, 1860
Dunbarton N.H.
Thursday, Aug 7, 1860
My dear Isaac, -
Father is going over to Concord this morning and I will write a sort of business letter to send by him to be mailed at C.  Yours of Friday Aug 3 reached here by the last mail containing all good news from you and a sheet from mother besides for which my best thanks.  I'll write her before long.  You ask about my money matters.  I have something over $10,00 now.  The bundle of dyed articles I expect to send for next Saturday and pay doubtless somewhere between four and five dollars.  I sent it to the Manchester agent, finding I should not have time to get it done in any other way.  Then if I find things

to sent.  I want to get a scarf and a reticule of some sort, the latter for myself and one for Anna also, if I can find anything I think will suit her and cost not more than two and a half or three dollars. Anna did not want to go above this I believe.  But it may be I cannot find anything.  I paid out to get from Worcester here three dollars and forty cents ($3,40).  Made some little purchases at Worcester and at Concord.  What the ticket from Cleveland to Worcester is I do no know.  Mr. Wilson game me $1,50 surplus I think.  It might have been $1,75, I do not remember exactly.  So you can judge what I shall need.  George can get money enough to get out there with, and what we pay for him need not be sent here.  Remember to direct to Westboro'.  Mrs. Walker has been here since saturday - goes over to Concord this morning with father.

on her way home.  We all visited yesterday at Capt. Kimballs.  Tuesday Mrs. John Kimball took tea here.  The thermometer yesterday and the day before went up to 91 degrees here, and was several degrees higher all around us.  I have not felt the heat so much before this summer.  We had thunder showers last night, and it is cloudy this morning but very warm.  
I am afraid mother is getting over tired.  I know you try not to have her.  Washing the little boys is pretty hard work for her.  I suppose they love to have her do it.
Love to all at home and all at the Dr's
In haste
Your loving Nettie

Nettie      Dunbarton
Aug. 2, 1860
Dunbarton, N.H.
Thursday, Aug. 2, 1860
My Dearest, -
Your good letter mailed Saturday morning, got here by Tuesday's mail. Came quick did it not?  You did not say a word about your cough and I wanted to hear that it was better.  Very glad the children do so well.  Charlie was three years old yesterday.  I guess I thought of it a dozen times.  Little May fifteen months.  I wish father & mother had some of those blackberries.  How nice they must be.  We have all the blueberries we want.  I have not seen a ripe blackberry yet.  Those Lawtons must be beautiful to look at.  I do not know how Zillah would make out canning them.  I should be a little afraid to trust her, she is so careless about doing things just right.  If you can sell them why not do so?  There will

be other things to can by and by.  That was quite a select pic nic.  Anna enjoyed it doubtless.  I suppose the Barn has grown a good deal.  You and Charles must not work too hard.  Last Monday Mr. & Mrs. Pelton were here sometime in the A.M.  talking somewhat of Cal.  He as been until now superintendent of schools in San Francisco.  Is just appointed to get up a model for a State Reform School to be established at Marysville 150 miles from San Fransisco.  He is to be the superintendent of that.  In the P.M. we all went and took tea with Miss Emerson by invitation and then George & I called over to Capt. Whipples and Mr. Safford's.  Tuesday, George and I went over to Concord.  Did a little shopping for father & mother, called at Dr. Colby's to tell him of father's health, dined at Dr. Colbys.  Called at Mr. Smarts and Mrs. Allisons.  At the latter place they said so very much to have us come in and sup with them when our errands were done, that we did.  We came off the

street to go there, we walked through the State house yard and, as there was no crowd, we walked almost up to the speaker's stand in front of the Entrance and saw Steven A. Douglas, face to face. He was having a public reception.  Arrived in the train at half past three from Vermont, where he had been visiting the scenes of his childhood.  I think he must have felt rather badly.  Many wonder at his coming to Concord.  The Democratic Party is split in twain, at least, there by Pierce coming out so decidedly for Breckenridge. Some of the leading Democrats managed to be out of the way that day.  Several started that day or the preceding on a journey, with their families.  The streets were profusely decorated with flags & streamers.  A professional decorator from Boston was hired to be there.  But the Lincoln & Hamlin Flags until noon, exceeded in No. the Douglas ones, and I do not know but they did all day.  At any rate they were about

equally divided.  When George and I got home we found Dr. Burbank of Yarmouth here.  I did not suppose he should see George; thought him still and Bangor and he would have been if I had not written to have him to supply for father.  Dr. B. must be over six feet in height, sixty five years old and a noble representative of the noble State of Maine - a genial, lively, energetic man.  The 'Call', remailed from Bangor, got here the same day. Dr B. said his son told him not to come home till he could tell them some definite news.  They had an idea that father was to be brought over to their side and then George would more easily be led to them.  I will tell you all about it when I get home.  The old Dr. could not be bent from his course at all, hardly wanted to speak of any thing else till that matter should be decided.  As he found G. at home he thought there was no need of delay - as he had had the thing before him for some weeks.  Knew that the call was sure to come as soon as legal action was taken.  The Call was dispatched to Bangor the very day of the action of the Parish.  It was written, and the signatures of the two Com's of Chh. and Parish obl. before they left the house on the day of the Parish meeting.  Dr B. stayed till ten or Eleven

comfortable to day.  I think he feels as if it was very doubtful about his preaching much more at all.  My father and mother are very frail creatures.  I hardly know which most so.  I wish, O so much, that a good man & wife could be found to come here & board them.
I wish I knew just what to do for myself.  For I do want to be well able to be very useful when I return to you.  I have a bout of sick headache a great part of the time - feel a little sick & faint & dizzy - I keep hoping it will all pass off of itself, but it seems to hold on.
My appetite is good enough, too good perhaps, but food does not set very well. 
I would not write this at all only

that perhaps you can suggest something I had better do.  But perhaps I shall feel quite well in a few days.
Kiss the dear children for me.  Much love to Mother & Charles & Charley Rich & all.  I lie down religiously every day.  Mrs. C. Kimball and her little girl (Nineteen days younger than little May) were here sometime this P.M.  Also Mrs. Brigham; and a niece of hers took supper.  Mrs. Brown & Agnes made long call since supper.  I wish there could be a good picture of Charley & Wilder together for father and mother.  They have none of either taken since they wore pants.
Love, Love from your own, Nettie.
I left a crochet needle at Mrs. Boyds.  Could you get it if you go that way?  It was a good one in a good case - a silver pencil case.  I do not like to lose it.

Nettie     Dunbarton
Aug. 5 1860
Dunbarton N.H.
Sabbath Eve, Aug. 5, 1860
My own dearest, 
I do feel about homesick to night, Isaac.  I do so long for you and the children.  Were it not for the Extreme feebleness of my father & mother, and their seeming so much to need the presence of a child to love & cheer, I could not be content.  The parents are really very feeble, Mother especially.  Father it think seems slowing gaining.  Looks & appears better than when I came - seems to be looking on the bright side.  Mother suffers a good deal every day.  She tried to go to Meeting all day to day, by lying down in the noon time, but when she had crept slowly and carefully home she was too faint to speak, till she had rested & taken some lavender.
I have two dollars and some over at present.

George preached all day & she wanted to hear him.  I shall try to persuade her never to try to go all day again.  It is altogether too much for her strength.  George went away to the Methodist house in the East part of town to lecture at five o'clock to night.  He has just returned.  Yesterday A. M. your letter written the 29 & 31 came, and the mail carrier brought out my old school mate Augusta Walker.  She heard I was home, and came from her home in Barnstead to see me. How glad & thankful we ought to be that the children are so well.  But you say nothing about your own cough. So I hope it is better.  Last Thursday George & I rode to the P.O. and mailed a letter to you, and then called at Mr. Rogers' &c.  Took tea at Mrs Brighams, thereafter called on Mrs. S. Burnham & Mrs. Twiss. Asenath (Mrs William Burnham) is sick with

fever, not able to see any one. Friday, I went with George to call at Dea Parker's - very pleasant call Louise & Abbie both at home.  Louise is going out this Fall to Ohio to spend the winter with Mary Ann in London.  Will have a chance to go to Elyria doubtless.  Abbie is a very sweet girl indeed.  Mr. Safford's two sisters are here visiting.  Dr. William Ryder from N. Orleans. There are strangers in attendance all over town.
A letter came from Westboro from the mother of that Miss Burgess, last Thursday saying that she would come, but she could not tell precisely when - probably could come about the time she will be needed.  I do feel troubled to think of the parents.  It seems as if they ought to be with a child - someone who feels interested for them.  I am very glad this Miss B. thinks she can come, but I feel as if it were doubtful

about her remaining - We can only try her & see.
Monday morn.  This is a delightful morning.  Father & mother have gone to ride.  George & Augusta and I have been walking & sitting on the grass under the apple tree East of the house.  Picked some gooseberries not so big as our Ohio ones.  Now we are to have some lemonade wherewith to regale ourselves, and then Augusta and I will lie & talk and dew a little.
Evening} Went by invitation to Dea Parker's to visit - got there about four - had fine time.  Home about eight,- and found William Bruntin and his sister, Mrs. Andrew Twiss waiting for us.
7th Tuesday morning.  This is a delightful morning.  We have had most delightful weather ever since I have been here.  Father and I are going this morning to call on Asenath.  She is better than she has been.  You speak of fruit.  I hope it will not be gone before we get back. If the apples are gone there will be something else just coming. We have any quantity of blueberries. Please direct the next letter to the care of Capt. Otis Brigham, Westboro, Mass.  We intend to leave him next Tuesday 14th.  If you send me some money it should come in pretty soon.  I did intend to make two or three more purchases, but perhaps shall find nothing to suit me.  
I want to get me a scarf because I need it all the while at Westboro.  Love to all, your own Nettie

Nettie    Dunbarton
Aug. 9, 1860
Dunbarton N. H.
Thursday Aug. 9, 1860
Dear Mother, -
I assure you I was glad to receive a letter from you, and to hear a continued good report from the children.  I fear you will weary yourself in trying to do so much for them.  Please be careful.  I remember just how careless & forgetful Zillah is & suspect you are sometimes not a little tried with her doings and her not doings.  I hope Anna can be up often and see you.  I am sitting all alone just now - about 2 P.M.  Father & mother both trying to rest.  I hear Father snoring so I guess he is sleeping, but poor mother keeps coughing still.  I am afraid she will not get asleep.  George is busy writing a sermon that he wants to finish this week.  He

finds so much to interrupt now that it is rather hard to work.  He thinks when he gets out-to-Elyria he won't be obliged to call & go calling everywhere and can write a little.   He wants to get a few sermons a head before he is settled.  We expect some young ladies here to tea this P.M. and we have a number of calls to return this week. My old friend Mrs. Walker (school mate at Gilmanton Acad.) left here this morning, having been here since Saturday.  I have had a nice visit from her.  Had not seen her before for nine years.  We are having extreme warm weather just now.  I wonder if it is very warm with you.  Hope Charles and Isaac will not work too hard.  People have not finished haying here yet, but they have very fine days for it - day after day of bright, hot sun
Friday morn - Father & mother both gone to ride

This morning George and I are going to return some calls by and by when they get home.  Father seems gaining slowly, we think, though still not able yet to study or read more than two or three minutes at once.
Monday Aug 13, It has been a dull rainy day till within two hours. It is now nearly four P.M. But at last the sun shines.  We are invited to Captain Whipple's to supper to night.  Last Saturday we took tea at Mr. Gays.  He is a man who has moved here from Boston within a year or two.  His wife has a sister from Boston, with three children, visiting here now.  Last Friday George and I called at Mr. John Tenney's (Isaac will know) and saw there Mrs. Tenney's sister, the wife of I. N. Metcalf of Lowell Ms.  She and two children were spending a few days there. She is a very pleasant lady, spoke particularly of Isaac's father and of you - and about little Mayo calling there with his father.
We shall start for Westboro Wednesday morning.  Cannot tell now exactly when we

shall leave there.  Probably just in season to get home next week.  I do think I might feel somewhat troubled my "two young girls" were-it-not-for the "supernatural body" you tell about.  In her skill and wisdom and abilities I have perfect confidence.  I only fear that you will feel so much care, and try to to so much yourself, as to get sick.  No matter if everything is not done.  Let everything pass that can till I get home.  How I want to see you all - and yet when I look at father & mother, I think O how much they do need a child to be with them.  I sometimes feel almost as if father would never preach again, or a least not many times more.  He cannot use his eyes five minutes without injury, and says he feels as if he should tumble to pieces for weakness.
Ever so much love to you from your affectionate daughter
Nettie.

Nettie     Dunbarton
Aug. 12, 1860
Dunbarton, Aug. 12,1860
My own dearest.-
This is Sabbath evening and I wonder how you and the dear little ones do and all the rest.  Wonder if you are writing to me.  I had a letter from you by mail of Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday of last week.  I did not expect one Saturday, but of course was very glad to see it.  George exchanged with Rev. Mr Day the Baptist minister of Weave; and he is a queer preacher.  I should prefer I think to hear Theodore L. Cuyler or Henry Ward Beecher, or even our excellent Mr. Wilbur or perhaps my own father or brother.  I could hardly sit still to hear him his words so moved me.  Father says he is glad

on the whole, of the exchange, for the people know now what sort of preaching they hear at Weave.  We did have a most excellent Sabbath School concert at the Vestry at five o'clock to night, conducted by good Charles Ryder in an able and appropriate manner.  It did seem good to see him stand up there, and read & comment on our Scripture in his clear, steady voice, pray himself and call on Charles Kimball to pray & when he said, "Will some one lead in prayer" to see Mr. Lewis Wilson rise and respond. It was an excellent meeting, and the Vestry was very nearly filled.
I must tell you what father is just saying about he day of preaching to George.  He says 'it was this thing and that thing and all sorts of things' a sort of boiled dish. George suggests and father says "yes, it was on the whole and Extraordinary production.

Well it is too dark to write.  I'll lay this by till tomorrow.

Tuesday morning - I wrote a little Sabbath evening while the rest were talking, and it it hardly worth sending.  Yesterday George and I employed part of a rainy forenoon in putting moss round some little pictures.  In the P.M. I finished letters to Anna and mother; and, about four, G or I went over to Capt. Whipples to tea.  Had a very pleasant time.  Everyone asks after you and a great many send love & respects &c.  This morning it rains again.  Hope it will not rain tomorrow, because it will be bad getting to the cars.  I did not mention in speaking of your letter, the safe arrival of the ten dollars.  If it had been thought of in season, I might have got money of father, and saved your sending it.  I paid for the coloring $4,14. for Anna and me together.  That I suppose I have not now enough to get home with.  If I do not get more from you at Westboro I can

borrow it.  I shall write to you, from Westboro, about our starting for Ohio.  I must pack my trunk to day with Georges help.  I rains so much & so hard I am afraid we can not get Jenny's cones Even if we could find a place to put them which would be very doubtful.
All send love - a great amount of it to you and kisses to the dear little trio from, Your own loving Nettie

Nettie    Westborough 
Aug. 18, 1860
Westboro., Mass -
Saturday, Aug 18, 1860
My own dear Isaac.  Yours mailed the 14th reached me last night.  The ten dollars (10,00) safely enclosed being all I need.  Good tidings again from all.  O if I only get home and find you all well, I think I shall be really thankful.
I am enjoying the visit here very much.  All the drawback is the lack of your presence.  I should be very glad to have you know some of these Uncles & cousins better.  We stopped with Aunt Lucy Pond the first night.  Most of Thursday at Uncle Otis', who lives in the same house, and yesterday morning came over here to Uncle Holloway O, in

the edge of Northboro.  To day we go over to Uncle Elmer's.
We find riper apples here, and all sorts of vegetables - squashes & green corn, blueberries & whortle berries.  We have a good morning walk and rides too.
About the shopping, I do not seem to have any opportunity to do it to advantage.  We stopped at Worcester long enough to do some but I found that being a stranger I sh'd pay as much for things as at home. Could I have an opportunity to go there with one of my cousins, I could do well.
I had brown bread and hominy for breakfast this morn.  It was good.  We intend to get to Elyria next Friday night if nothing occurs to prevent (Aug 24)
Great love to all from Nettie

Nettie
Sept. 4 1860
Elyria, Tuesday Sept 4, 1860
My dearest Isaac - 
When Charlie came from the P.O. this evening he brought a letter from Dunbarton, one for Charles from Albina and the enclosed from Eliab.  Albina's chief news is that Mr. Severance's dog had run mad and been killed, but before he met his fate he bit a number of dogs in the region, and Rover among the rest.  Rover had forthwith been killed also as the safest course.  Charlie feels quite bad about it.  Sarah Burgess had reached Dunbarton.  Mother thinks her very slow, but I guess she will do well.  George reached home safely.  Hattie came up while he was gone, to charge him

with being unsocial and to ask him to meet the newly formed Young Ladies Reading Circle, at Dr. DeWitt's, tomorrow evening.  It is to be at different houses each week.  Gentlemen in the evening, to be invited, according to the preferences of the young lady who entertains the circle.  Young ladies to read from three to five & have a simple supper there after.  Hattie wants George to take 'Mary' and carry her up to Mr. Halls, in the morning to invite Hiram and get him to invite more gentlemen for her.  I should think father and mother both very feeble from the letter.
Baby has walked four or five times this evening.  So she will get ready to sleep for the night I imagine.  It is about as warm

as any night we have had, I should think.  I hope you write.  Have a comfortable night.
Your own loving Nettie

Nettie
Sept. 8, 1860
Elyria, Ohio 
Saturday Eve. Sept. 8, 1860
My dear one - 
Half past seven it is. Children all sleeping - homework all out of the way.  Sarah sewing in the kitchen.  Charles & George here at the table in the dining room.  The former reading, the latter planning a sermon.  All is pleasant within, but without the rain pours steadily, as it has done all day, and most of last night. We have had in the course of the rain very heavy thunder indeed.  We have just been looking over a package of deeds, six of them, that to night's mail brought from Mr. Keyes.  I do not see as we can do anything about them and we have been deliberating whether

they could be made out without my signature when you get to Du Quoin.  There came one deed last night with a letter from Mr Keyes and a Draft for $50.00. Also came last night your letter from Cincinnati, which I was glad enough to see. Wonder if you are safe in Du Quoin to night.  I wish I knew.  But take it for granted you have prospered.  I mailed a letter from Eliab Wednesday morning. G. carried Hattie up to Mr. Hall's and brought Jenny up here, about 10, Wednesday A.M. Started about eight.  Jenny stayed till three P.M. and George carried her home.  About four Herbert came with a stable horse and he & George went to Black River - had a good ride, bathed in Lake Erie & were back at half past Eight.
Thursday Anna & Hattie were up here in the morning.  I went back with them

to go in to Emilies, to see if she knew of a girl for me.  (She did not) and Wilder walked down with Hattie & stayed till five.  George went and called at Mr Wilbur's, and in the P.M. on Mr. Monteith.  Got his sermon and a chapter of advice, to the end that he had better carefully revise & improve said sermon, and proceed forthwith to publish it.  He took tea at Mr. Brooks.  Mrs. Montieth and her son John arrived this same night.  Friday I found how the tomatoes were decaying, and went to work and canned four quarts. Herbert came up in the P.M. and he & G. went to walk by riverside.  Herbert here to supper.  George back with him to P.O. and returned with your letter, and the one deed and letter from Du Quoin.  Anna came up a few moments. Said mother did not

seem well and wanted some blackberry root for her - told me the great news of the day, which was that the night before thieves broke in to Mr. Cranes and took $40,00 worth of silver, into Mr. Goodspeeds & took half a dozen double plated spoons, tried Mr Cooley's and he heard and got up frightening them away.  Got into Mr. Burks breaking two lights from a French window upsetting a kerosene lamp on to a nice carpet, and carrying off somethings.  I forgot what.  They tried to get in to the Dr's and got a window up in the Library, took out Anna's work basket, which stood on a table in front of the window and they found it in the grass outdoors by an over turned flower pot, and her gold spectacles missing from it.  Anna was up several times in the night and went into the bathing room with a light and they suppose this only saved all their silver.  They heard no noise at all I believe.  No clue to the robbers.  Dr feels as if he wanted to cane them, or take a poker to them, that was it, I guess.  Everyone is sorry for poor Mr Crane.  He says he shouldn't have believed it could have been done without rousing them.

5) Baby has done nicely ever since you left and seems to feel quite well for her.  I keep blackberry root steeped for her.  Wilder has been about sick to day.  He seemed this morning to be threatened strongly with dysentery.  I have been giving him the blackberry root tea and only a little dry bread to eat. Have keep him in the house all day and lying down most of the time, and he seems better to night, and I hope will really prove to be so tomorrow.  Discharges slimy & somewhat bloody this morning, quite changed to night.  I cannot but feel anxious, did not know but he ought to have some strong medicine .  If he is not really better still in the morning, write and send to Dr DeWitt.
A letter from home the night you left which I told you about, I think.
Sabbath Eve - I'll finish this that it may be sent by the morning mail.  I did not go to meeting this A.M. Wilder needed watching and care, though he is really better. George took Mr.

Christed to the Sabbath School this P.M.  I think he enjoyed hearing the class.  He preached this eve at seven o'clock.  About as many out as usually attend the morning service.  I went leaving the little people all sleeping, and Sarah and Charles to keep house.  Baby, to make up for the loss of her father, takes an unusual liking to George.  She will go to him from my arms, and stretch out her arms to him, when sitting in her chair, or on the floor.  Whether she mistakes him for you or not, I do not know.
Monday Sept 10 - Wilder is better.  Says he feels well.  He is five years old today.  Says "tell papa so and that I am a good boy, and can chop wood, now I'm five years old."  It is a very cold morning.  Charles & George are going to Cleveland, so I am in a hurry about breakfast.

Nettie
Sept12, 1860
Elyria Sept.12, 1860
My very dear Isaac
Just nine of the clock it is, but I must write a little to you to night.  This as been an unusually busy day to day.  Did I write to you that Sarah has a Shaker Sabbath night?  So I have been very careful to have nothing done that could be let alone.  Washing for this week is not done yet.  I went to day to engage a washerwoman to come Friday.  I did a little sewing at Annas this A.M., and took the cans to be repaired to Northrup, tried to find some peaches, went to Miss Reeves, and to the bakers &c.  George took me in the carriage.  Home to dinner at half past twelve.  Then caring for

and Charlie (Wilder went to school today with Mary)  Sweeping and dusting, talking with Mrs. Mussey (H. E.) Gathering tomatoes &c till four o'clock.  Then G. carried me round to see Jenny and tell Mr Brooks that I could not keep the S. S. Class, and to the Dr's to ask him what should we do for Sarah.  I gave her Quinine twice today, in very small doses, but she threw both up at once.  She has had diarrhea for some time she says.  Dr said alternative pills she must have.  Went to Jenkins & got some.  Then home & while Sarah sat the table & George took care of baby I made biscuits for supper.  Helped Sarah clear table.  Got baby to sleep &c &c and sat down here to write.  George writing too.  Charles reading newspapers.  I have just finished writing home to go with George.  A letter from Eliab and one from Hattie Ely to day received by Mrs. S. M. Metcalf,

brings the news of the birth of "bouncing boy' of ten lbs. weight who arrived there Sept. 2.  Marie's comfortable.  Little Edith 18 days younger than baby May!
I hope you have received the letter from Eliab.  He speaks of it as being of importance to him.  Mother has been feeling rather miserable for two or three days, but said she felt much better this afternoon.  Clara is up here to night to stay with Sarah.  George and Charles enjoyed the trip to Cleveland very much.  There was a great crowd and a great parade.  21 cars from Elyria.  600 tickets sold at this station.  People to be counted by acres.  Statue, very fine it is said.  They got home just at nine.  Mr Wilbur was up here twice yesterday (once in the AM when George was down to Mr. Brooks) to see if

he could arrange with George to supply for him next Sabbath & he go to Clinton to preach for a destitute people.  The proposition was made by two of the elders of the church.  I suppose Mr. Wilbur will go to Clinton, & G. preach here.  When he returned from Mr Brooks yesterday just after dinner, he was caught in a drenching shower and wet to the skin.  Put on some stockings of yours, your old pants, &c and it took the P.M. to get his own dried.  Shoes and stocking soaked, pants could be wrung, collar decidedly limber, hat dripping with water, no harm done.  It is really cold for the season.  We have fire in the furnace about every morning.  Wilder continues better but needs close watching & care about exercise & diet.
Good night.  Hope you are well & His love and blessings & guidance be with you who will care for us all while we are apart.  Lovingly your Nettie

Nettie Oct. 14 1861
Elyria, Monday Oct. 14, 1861
My very dear Isaac 
You mailed at Columbus Oct 11, reached me Saturday evening.  I wanted to sit down at once & write to you to mail this morning, but was so tired after reading the evening paper that I did not do it, & it seems as if everything conspired against my writing to day.  The AM was as busy one as Monday forenoon is wont to be and this P.M. I sat down and just finished a letter to father that I wrote last week chiefly, and had taken my paper to talk to you and Mrs Mussey & Flora came & stayed nearly two hours, I should think.

Mother went down to Anna's about ten this morning.  Charlie took her carpet bag and 1/2 bushel of grapes for Miss Finn in the little carraige, and she walked.  They all go to Sandusky tomorrow morning, Dr & Anna, Mother & Libby.  Mother goes directly to Perkins, expects Mr Haldman to meet her.  Anna wrote to him & to the Mrs Barney.  They do not think to return till Saturday.  Dr & Libby may come Thursday.  Charlie has been a good boy.  The horse Mary swam over or waded over, the river last night.  Charlie got her back.  He and Gertrude walked up to the wood lot last Saturday, starting at half past two & returning by five, and got half a bushel

of nuts ready shucked.  They area very plenty.  They could gather them by the handful.
Last Saturday noon Mrs MacIntyre and old Mrs Hetherton came.  Mrs MacIntyre was out of flour and they were out at Baldwins where her order stands.  I offered to lend her or give her a few lbs and she went to see Mr Paddock to day if she could, but she had her baby and couldn't carry it very well and wanted an order.  I wrote one on Starr Brother's & Co. signing it I. S. Metcalf, per Mrs Metcalf.  Was it proper?  Mrs Hetherton I gave a loaf of bread, and told her to try to see Mr Paddock to day. Have had no post yet.  Beautiful weather.  Wilder says he is going to be very good.  Little May was quite disconsolate after

you had gone.  She said "my Father is gone and your Isaac is gone" "and he is danmuner's Isaac too," she said.
