I do wish you could find time to write to father while you are gone.  I think about him so much.  He must feel very lonely & strange.  Mother always waited on him so carefully that he will hardly know where to go or what to do.  
No frost yet, but pretty cold night & morning.  Have not gathered Catawabas yet.  Made nine bowls of jam - very nice.
No meeting sabbath A.M. Mr. Wilbur gone to Presbytery. S. I. Concert in P.M. at Episcopal chh.  I went with the boys.  Heard the Rev Baptist Leanord speak.  A perfect contrast to Mr. Heyhunst.  Seemed to have quite a faculty of interesting children.  Regular western man, I should imagine.  Good night, your Nettie.
Love to Mrs Keyes and Mr Keyes as well.

Nettie   Oct 16, 1861
Elyria Oct 16. 1861
My Dearest - 
Two letters just received lie before me, both from your dear self, one mailed at Cincinnati Oct. 11, the other Du Quoin Monday morning, I do feel greatly relieved to know of your safe arrival at Du Quoin.  You had time in Cin. for a nice long visit.  I mailed a letter to you yesterday morning.  Mother and the rest went, as expected, to Sandusky.  The Mrs Pauper Gates came yesterday noon to display her receipt of goods & to know if you would pay the transportation.  Said she had not a cent to pay it with. I sent her to Mr Paddock.  "The Lord knows" she said, "I shall have to come back onto 'Lyra if they dont pay it, for I cant lose all my goods."  She expects her brother

this week.  A great tall ragged boy came yesterday too, and wanted to ascertain if Mr Maddock lives here.  A Mr Mountain, tailor formerly working for Starr Brothers, now for Mendel and Spitzenberg, came to look at Riggs house.  Said he would pay 1 dollar per week and pay at the end of each week.  I told him about paying in advance.  He said he never had, but would pay each week as above.  I told him I would let him know if he would call again at to night after trying to have him wait for your return.  He said he must have a house this week.  Three children none very small.  I went to Mr Tift of whom he had rented a part of the house just opposite Dr. DeWitt's.  The gave him a good character, said he was honest & peaceable, knew his own business & minded it.  She lived two years

in the house with him.  So I ventured to say yes to Mr Mountain when he appeared in the Evening,  I do not feel sure that you will think I have done properly in the matter, but hope all is right.  I thought at first I would tell him I could do nothing about it, but he said the house just suited him, and he should be very glad or it.  Yesterday Gertrude and I have had the parlor carpet up & shaken it & got all right again in there.  Found some moths.  The carpet had been down too long.  It is about three years isn't it?  Glad Du Quoin is so fine a place.  I should surely wish we lived there on many accounts, if I did not believe everything about our affairs is directed by Wisdom above our own. I should like to send my love to all the good ladies I know who remember me, I should

I read the evening papers all to myself and mourn & lament over the Freeman's troubles.  What does it mean?  I read the papers aloud when mother was here,

very much love to see them all.
Charlie does very well - rather a hickory nut fever, but I imagine it will pass away.  He has today fastened Mary into the barn.  She would get away over the river and we feared she would get quite away. Mr. Waldo advised to tie her up in the barn, so it is done.  We have not had frost that was discernible here, though Dr. said he found some ice Monday morning on some of his squashes.  Since then the weather has been much warmer.
I sat right down to write this evening, and shall mail this tomorrow morning, so that you may get it before you leave Du Quoin.  Hattie has Miss Woodbury to stay with her but is so lonesome during the day that she begs for Wilder & Charlie to come stay with her.  The will go a little while tomorrow.  Jenny's girl is sick and gone home.  I am lonesome these evenings.  Little May is very good.  Talks about "my dear papa."
Good night, your loving Nettie

Nettie    Oct. 21 1862
Elyria, Oct 21, 1862
My dearest Isaac - 
Yours, mailed at Du Quoin on the 18th reached us to night making us all very glad of it, being the first we have heard from you since you left.  The 'pencilling' you speak of has not yet arrived.  We began to be anxious.  Didn't know but the guerrillas had found you, or something as bad.  I thought of writing the day after you left, but concluded to wait for your first letter.  Am sorry now that I did not write.  We have had no trouble since you left, only little May has not been very well.  Has vomited every night for three nights, and looks sallow and dull-eyed.  Still she does not seem very unwell, is determined to

work at all hazards.  She went out this P.M. and picked up under the trees three heaped-full baskets of apples.  I asked her this morning if she thought father was thinking about his little May.  She said,"No, he is thinking about his Coal Mines."  Charlie Rich has taken care of the sweet Potatoes & hoed some.  Worked over beans some, &c.  Hattie DeWhitt was here Friday and spent most of the day.  Anna was here Thursday.  Herbert and Jennie called this P.M.  
Mr Hitchcock sent for the grapes & a bushel of peaches.  left some on the tree for Herbert, but before he got them, somebody else did.  We have had frost two mornings, but not severe. The balsams and cypress vine look forlorn, but I do not see as it injured any thing else.
Sorry for the sick people out

at Du Quoin.  Love to old friends there.  I should like to see Mrs Keyes book, so would mother, but I do not know as it best to buy one.  You can judge best.
I'll cut out the latest 'local item' and send it to you.  Last night Baldwin's Wellingtons store was broken into, and a large amount carried away.
You may not get this, but I thought it possible you might.  Will not seal it till morning, so I can tell you "what of the night".  Mother is holding baby while I am writing.  She is well as usual.
Wednesday, morn, 22 (6 1\4 o'clock)}  We are are all up and dressed but baby and all doing nicely.  May did not vomit at all in the night.  Wilder is going right to the P.O. with this.  He says, "tell father that mother tied a string around my loose tooth, and I pulled it out

myself, and a new one is coming & another loose."  No frost last night.  A cloudy night =  E. T. Curtis lectures this evening in the Methodist church.
With much love, your own Nettie.

Nettie Jan 30, '68
Elyria Ohio
Friday, P.M. Jan. 30, 1863
Dearest -,
I received a letter from you Wednesday, and another from Chicago to day.  It does us all good to hear from you.  Glad to hear from Mr Rowley too.  Dr was up here yesterday morning, said the walk quite exhausted him.  He has not been well since Sabbath.  Libbie is getting better.  Anna has been sick, too - has not been out of the house this week, I believe - cold and sore throat, with some fever.  She was up writing letters yesterday.  I went down there just before supper time to see how they did.  Mr. Waldo got a small load of wood yesterday, but says it almost killed his horse.
To day it snows again.  We called

Mr Waldo in this morning to see if he could do the pump any good.  It gave out again, all at once while Gertrude was pumping, yesterday morning. But Mr Waldo could not remedy it.  Said he guessed Mr Lane would have to do it.  Yesterday was a fair day for a wonder.  There came a letter again from Mr Keyes.
In the evening came an invitation for you & me to visit at Mr Hurlbert's this evening.  Dr and Anna are invited, Mr & Mrs Mussey, Ely's, Brooks', &c.  To day Mary Dascomb came over to dinner.  She hopes to go home to night, but I do not believe her father will come.  The 'going' is terrible.
The children all make noise enough to be pretty well.  We use the linament for all of them, May's throat looks improving.

The dear baby's nose is an exceeding bother to the little thing.  She gets her patience utterly exhausted with it.  I do hope it will get better ere long.  But better her nose than her throat.  Wilder has just finished his lessons for to day. 'Gerrie' came over last night and told him about to day's lessons.
This does not seem to be much of a letter but there does not seem to be much to write.  This afternoon is church meeting, but none of us go.
We had, I forgot to tell you, a letter today from Mr Keyes again, the third since you left; and mother had one from Samuel. He's on two Committees - Commerce and Public Lands.
All good be and abide with you.  So wishes your Nettie.

Mother says take good care of your health while you are gone.  She has just got baby to sleep. We are all doing nicely and hope you are safe at Du Quoin before this.
Nettie

Nettie Jan 30, '63
Elyria, Ohio
Tuesday Jan 27, 1863
Dearest - Eight o'clock P.M. Baby asleep in her cradle, breathing pretty hard but no worse than she has for several days.  The other children fast asleep, too.  Wilder had had a fine nap, perspired freely and seems doing well.  I gave him a dose of oil to night.  I has snowed steadily all day long.  Mrs Herman Ely sent her man here this forenoon after that Program of S. S. Lessons on the Transfiguration of Our Savior, that she lent you some time since.  I happened to find it, and sent it back to her.  Anna has decided not to go to Cleveland.  Sarah C. goes tomorrow morning.  It seems lonesome enough.

this stormy night without you.  Hope you are safe & comfortable somewhere.  Wilder says I must tell you he has learned all his lessons to day, & recited them too.  Charley Rich brought home his books for him at noon.
Wednesday, P.M.  Charley brought a letter this morn from yourself, mailed at Sandusky.  Also one from Mr Keyes, and one from father.  Yesterday came one from B. Sprague to you about Herbert's business matter, he did not having heard from Herbert since writing. I sent it over to Herbert to day.  Father says "as to the transfer of the money, I am too poor to run any risks.  Having no income at all but the interest of my money, and not a great deal of that & having constant outgoes, I feel the necessity of investing what money I have so that it will

be perfectly safe, or I may lose my means of livelihood.  H's enterprise is an experiment concerning which I know nothing, and its success is all in the dark future."
Father had been four weeks at Yarmouth, health very good for him.  Expects to remain there for the present, giving another trial to the climate.
Wilder is full enough of life to day to be pretty well, is evidently much better. Took a dose of castor oil last night and has used the alum gargle pretty faithfully.  May's throat is swollen a good deal yet.  We keep rubbing it with the linament, quite against her wishes.  she says it gets into her eyes and makes the smart.  We have got a new rule now - Grandmother holds her hand over her eyes while I rub it on.  I have

written thus far with baby in my arms, but stopped to get her to sleep.  Now she is in her cradle making a great noise about breathing. Charlie is standing by me.  Says - "Mother I feel lonesome without father".  May is rather fretful. She says "tell father I want him to come home."  Charlie Rich is just bringing in the milk.  He is going about clearing off the snow from the door steps.  It has not snowed to day, but has been cloudy all day.  I hope it will clear away before long.  Mother seems lonesome and homesick.  You being away and the weather so bad that Anna does not get here "Darkness falls from the wings of night".  So I stop.
Lovingly Nettie
P. Aid Soc. have an Oyster Supper at Ely Hall next Tuesday Eve.

Nettie    Feb 2 1863
Elyria. Ohio 
Feb 2, 1863
My dearest - 
I am sitting in our nursery close by baby's cradle while I write.  Baby I guess is getting along well, but her nose is a great trouble to her at present.  It takes her a long time to get to sleep. It seems sometimes as if she could not breathe at all through her nose, and it provokes her terribly.  
We felt pretty anxious about May yesterday & last night, were on the point of sending for the Dr. several times.  She was feverish and restless and her throat sore.  We gave her a little blue pill and a little Dove's Powder last.
Charlie does very well. Guess he tries to be good and faithful.  I have hardly done anything but look after the children since you left.  Don't know what I should have done without Mother. We hope Anna will be able to be up here tomorrow perhaps to spend the day.
Your own Nettie

night and some this morning.  She slept quietly after twelve during the night and seemed greatly better this morning and so continues.  She had a fine nap this forenoon. Wilder has gone to school this P.M. He and Charly make noise enough to be well, though Wilder has some cold yet.  He gargles salt and vinegar and little May takes Alum water in her mouth and holds it a minutes & spits it out.  I think enough comes in contact with her throat to help it some.  Charlie and May are eating pop corn and trying to save a little for Wilder.  May has hardly tasted anything since Saturday noon, but seems to feel nicely now.
Have not heard from Mrs Nelson to day, but she has been very low, so that they felt great fears for

her life.  Dr Townsend has been to see her.
There came Saturday a letter from Mr Keyes, mailed on his way to Springfield and enclosing check for $100,00.  Shall send it to Dr. at the bank, shall I ?
Mary Dascomb to dinner to day.  She likes Dwight Rockwell very much.  Was'nt he troublesome at one time in the schools?  She says he is just right.
Letter from yourself this noon announcing your safe arrival at Du Quoin.  Singular about Ghetty's fancy for the coal mine.  Probably will not last long. What does he do with his money.  There is a chance for him to earn quite a pile before he is a man, if he is steadfast.  Letter too, this noon

from Eliab and Maria.  Dated 26 Jan.  Perhaps I will enclose it to you.  Must anything be done with the deed he sends till you come?   Mr. Waldo drew some more wood to day.  A man came up to get directions about making Hat Stand.  He will have to wait till you come home, I suppose.  It has been pretty cold to day  Has not thawed very much even with sunshine.
They are all better at the Dr's I believe.  Dr was up here last evening to see how we all were.  Charlie Rich went to meeting. Said Mr Brooks was not at Sabbath School, was at home sick.  Mr Wilbur took charge.
I almost forgot to tell you Gertrude is having her turn with sore throat.  It has been inflamed a good deal with some cankers.  She has used alum and taken blueing with good Effect.  Did not wash to day, because not feeling able.

Nettie  Feb. 5 1863
Elyria, Feb. 5, 1863
My very dear Isaac,
I was intending to write you yesterday, but the time seemed to be so occupied that I did not, and now I have to acknowledge the receipt of a nice long letter from yourself, written Feb. 1. But you say you have heard not a word from home.  I sent a letter to the office the evening of Wednesday, the day after you left, and another Friday, and another last Monday.  I have received the fourth from you. You will want first & foremost to hear from the children. I wrote that I let Wilder go to school on Monday P.M.  Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday were very pleasant days.  But to day it has snowed very fast all day long, and

the  storm & cold together I thought might be too harsh for him.  So he is at home today again.  His throat is some sore yet.  Charlie seems to feel finely.  Little May's throat is greatly sore.  Sabbath day she had some fever and yesterday a return of the same.  We thought, for the sake of feeling more safe, we would ask Dr Strong to come and see her.  He came last night, and she has taken three powders that he left for her, and had no perceptible fever about her to day.  We will take just as good care of her as we possibly can.  I imagine she will feel much better tomorrow.  Baby is much better.  Her breathing is greatly improved.  Gertrude calls herself well again.  Blue pill & alum gargle cured her at once.  Mother is singing to the little folks while I am writing.  May has been playing with her

paper dolls very busily, and is resting a little now.  Wilder and Charlie have had a flat-iron and ironed - on the floor, all the towels and diapers they could find.  Anna was here yesterday P.M.  Did not get here in season to help us eat our nice little fat turkey that we saved a day longer on purpose for her, thinking she was coming to spend the day!  Mary D. did not come to dinner either yesterday.  So we had it to ourselves.  Mary came to day though and had some served cold.  Anna has severe cold & looks about sick.  Charlie Rich came in at noon yesterday with two fingers bleeding.  Mother questioned him about how they became cut, and he said he did it on the ice getting Gay Pond out of the river.  It turned out that as he was going down to the Office at noon, just this

side of Mr Snow's he heard a noise but thought nothing of it at first.  Then heard someone calling Mr Snow, Mr Snow and ran toward the river to see what the matter was - found Gay holding on to the ice with cold fingers.  He ran to Mrs. Snow's door to let her know and tell somebody lest he could not succeed in rescuing him.  Got a board and pushed it out on the ice so Gay could reach it and lever him out by its means just as Mr. Laundon & others got there.  Mrs. Snow said there was no ice at all the day before in the place where he went in.  Gay said, "I'll never go skating on that branch again", but I'm afraid he will.
I will write again tomorrow or next day.
Please keep well and do good and we know you always come home sooner than you can.  So I need not say anything about that.
Lovingly Nettie

Nettie Feb. 7, 1863
Elyria, Saturday, Feb 7 /63
My dear Isaac,
I want to write a little this A.M., but must do it in great haste.  You will want most to hear about the children.  Baby slept beautifully last night, better than all before since you left.  The boys are doing well, only trouble is to look after them and keep them away from cold and see that they do not over eat.  May we think is some better this morning.  The great trouble has been, in the night, about her breathing; but she slept nicely the last part of the night, and her nose discharging considerably to day, to our great

delight.  Throat still pretty sore by not worse.
Got another letter from you yesterday written after you had received one from home.
Dr said I could put your name on that Bank Check.  So I did and he sent to for collection.  He has ?U S. Bonds for you, very advantageously he thinks, has them at the Bank.
In haste lovingly 
Nettie?
Good sleighing and we get along nicely about wood.  More snow and cold weather.
